entry.title: Boost your CAP Development with AI: Introducing the MCP Server for CAP
entry.content:
Imagine the following: You are an experienced developer, working on SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) projects. You use AI agents, such as Claude Code, opencode, or GitHub Copilot, to support you in your daily work. Wouldn't it be cool if the used LLM can help you develop CAP applications? With our new MCP server for CAP, we can provide more context about your project as well as relevant CAP examples to steer the LLM in doing the right thing.

 

What is an MCP Server?

An MCP (Model Context Protocol) server is designed to manage and deliver capabilities to Large Language Models (LLMs) via AI agents. It bridges the gap between LLMs and external resources such as services, tools, and data, enabling LLMs to interact with these resources. The newly introduced MCP server for CAP transforms AI agents into CAP development experts. It provides context-focused tools that aim to help the AI agent to answer questions such as:

  • Which CDS (Core Data Services) services does my project expose and where are they served?
  • What are the entities about and how do they relate to each other?
  • How do I add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js?
  • How can I register custom READ handlers in CAP Java?

 

The MCP Server for CAP

In the context of the assisted development introduced in the beginning, this means: You might ask the LLM to add, for example, a bound action `setToCompleted` to the entity `Orders`. Without our new MCP server for CAP, the LLM would hallucinate and could invent a new syntax and do a lot of file searches to find the relevant file. With the help of our new MCP server for CAP the LLM behaves as intended. To do so, the LLM generates a tool call to check the Orders entity and relevant information is returned, such as its elements and file location. It also generates a tool call to check the CAP documentation for bound actions. Based on the results, it generates the correct CDS code to add the bound action. This, of course, is just one example. We designed our MCP server for CAP to help you with arbitrary tasks instead of focusing on single commands.

For this purpose, our newly introduced MCP server for CAP provides the following two tools for AI-assisted development of CAP applications:

search_model

This tool allows the AI model to perform a fuzzy search for CDS definitions (entities, services, actions) within a unified compiled CDS model of all your .cds files. This CDS model includes the model structure and relationships, annotations and metadata, and the generated HTTP endpoints.

The fuzzy search algorithm matches definition names and supports partial matches, making it easy to find entities such as "Books" even when searching for "book".

search_docs

This tool enables the AI model to perform a semantic search through the preprocessed  CAP documentation, which is stored locally as embeddings. The search query is converted to an embedding vector. Finally, a similarity search is performed to find the relevant parts of the documentation, which have the highest semantic similarity to your query even if the exact keywords are not used.

Please note: These tools are meant to be used by AI models and do not constitute a stable API. But for experimental purposes, you can also use the tools directly from the command line as documented here: MCP server for AI-assisted development of CAP applications.

 

Try it out

Are you excited to try it out? Detailed instructions can be found here: MCP server for AI-assisted development of CAP applications.

Important: Our MCP Server for CAP is designed to support professional developers in their daily work. As with all AI-generated information, you should check the generated results carefully to avoid unintended side effects.

We are excited to announce that the MCP Server for CAP is an open-source project, licensed under the Apache-2.0 license. Learn more about open source at SAP.

We are very curious to see what you will do with our MCP server for CAP! Please don't hesitate to provide your feedback here or report any issues in our GitHub repository.

 

Beyond CAP

We also offer a UI5 MCP server and an MCP server for SAP Fiori, ensuring that you have a comprehensive suite of tools to enhance your development workflow across various SAP technologies. You can find the packages here: UI5 MCP server and MCP server for SAP Fiori.

The introduction of the MCP servers for CAP, SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori marks a significant step forward in leveraging AI to enhance developer productivity.

Stay tuned for more updates. Happy coding!

entry.title: SAP Fiori Tools Update – First Release of the SAP Fiori MCP Server for Agentic AI Workflows
entry.content:
We’re excited to announce the release of the SAP Fiori MCP server, a new capability that lets AI coding assistants directly create and edit SAP Fiori applications. This marks the next milestone in our AI journey, following the Project Accelerator introduced earlier this year.

What is MCP — and why it matters?

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard that standardizes how applications provide context to large language models. MCP is already supported by clients such as Claude, Cline, Cursor, and VS Code allowing AI-powered workflows to interact seamlessly with developer tools.

Introducing the SAP Fiori MCP server

The SAP Fiori MCP server (@sap-ux/fiori-mcp-server) is an open-source node.js module delivered as part of the open-ux-tools repository. It enables developers using AI coding assistants to generate and adapt SAP Fiori elements applications with precision and context awareness.

It is not the only MCP server published by SAP. The CAP MCP server (@cap-js/mcp-server) provides tools to create and modify CAP node.js projects, and the UI5 MCP server (@ui5/mcp-server) allows AI assistants to write SAPUI5 code. Together, these servers provide complementary entry points into different areas of SAP application development, so that AI assistants can seamlessly data models, SAP Fiori applications, and SAPUI5 code.

For more information also have a look at the related blog posts:

  • Boost your CAP Development with AI: Introducing the MCP Server for CAP
  • Give Your AI Agent Some Tools: Introducing the UI5 MCP Server

With the MCP servers in place, you can already try out scenarios such as:

  • “Please add an SAP Fiori elements list report app to my CAP project.”
  • “Generate a new CAP project and SAP Fiori app based on my_sketch.png.”
  • “Add Flexible Column Layout to the app.”
  • “Enable initial load for the SAP Fiori app.”

⚠️ Note: The SAP Fiori MCP server is currently released in experimental state and subject to rapid change and enhancements.

AI assistants can discover and act on SAP Fiori projects

The first release comes with a set of capabilities designed to let AI assistants both discover and act on SAP Fiori projects. The SAP Fiori MCP server provides tools to generate SAP Fiori elements applications for CAP node.js projects, finds SAP Fiori applications in the workspace, and allows to edit applications and pages inside applications.

To ensure that the AI produces correct results, we propose rules that guide the LLM’s behavior (see rules). These rules cover important aspects such as using proper SAP Fiori elements application patterns, ensuring data models are valid with UUID primary keys, generating sample data consistently, and preferring code-based modifications over screen personalization.

You can configure the server to be directly called with npx or install it globally via npm (see usage). In both cases, it integrates easily into an MCP-enabled client such as Cline.

Example how the SAP Fiori MCP server is used in Cline.

Developers can build apps more quickly using MCP servers

By connecting directly into SAP Fiori projects through MCP, developers gain a much more cost-effective way to experiment with AI support. They can let LLMs execute complex tasks in context—while the built-in functions and rules ensure adherence to SAP Fiori best practices. This reduces the risk of hallucinations, accelerates prototyping, and makes it easier to iterate quickly on new ideas. Since the SAP Fiori MCP server is with other MCP servers like UI5 and CAP, developers can benefit from a consistent AI-driven experience across different parts of the development process.

This is the first step on the MCP journey

The current release is just the first step. We are already working on extending the server with a document search feature that will make guidance from SAP documentation, tutorials, and examples directly available to the LLM. This means that the AI assistant won’t just follow rules embedded in the server but can also draw from the wealth of published learning content.

In addition, the generator functionality, which in the first release is limited to CAP node.js projects, will be expanded to support any suitable OData source. This will significantly broaden the scenarios in which the SAP Fiori MCP server can be applied, giving developers much more flexibility in how they use AI to create and adapt applications.

Try the SAP Fiori MCP server at SAP TechEd 2025

You can experience the SAP Fiori MCP server live at SAP TechEd Berlin. In session CA261 – Create great UX with AI, SAP Design System, SAP Fiori elements, and SAPUI5, we’ll guide you through using AI and MCP to generate applications, adapt them, and extend them with SAPUI5. It’s a hands-on workshop designed to show how these new capabilities come together in practice.

Closing

This release marks the start of a new era in SAP Fiori development, where AI assistants can not only suggest but also execute tasks reliably. With upcoming enhancements like doc search and broader generator support, we’re laying the groundwork for smarter, faster, and more flexible AI-driven development. As an open-source project we also welcome your contributions. We encourage you to report any issues you encounter. Your feedback is invaluable to us.

We can’t wait to see how you experiment with it—and we look forward to meeting you at TechEd!

entry.title: SAP Partners - Fast Track your SAP Business Technology Platform Certification Path
entry.content:
SAP Business Technology Platform Certification Path – From Beginner to Advanced

Are you interested in getting your SAP Business Technology Platform ( SAP BTP)  certification, but unsure of where to begin?

In this blog, we would like to give you a better overview of the available SAP BTP certifications and guide you how to progress from foundational level to professional expertise. Additionally, we will introduce several enablement offerings, specifically designed for SAP Partners,  that can help you fast track your SAP BTP certification. 

Depending on your existing knowledge and skills, you can determine which of the three steps below is the ideal starting point for you.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Step 1- Entry-Level Certification

For partners who are new to SAP’s ecosystem, one of the best starting points to learn the basics of SAP Business Suite and the importance of SAP BTP is the entry level certification “Positioning SAP Business Technology Platform as part of the SAP Business Suite”.

This certification takes you through the foundational courses of the SAP Business Technology Platform, enabling the enhancement of business processes through the integration of intelligent technologies, the development of innovative applications, and the analysis and visualization of data.

  • For SAP Partners, we offer bi-weekly 90 minutes webinars that are led by SAP experts and will provide the clarity, focus, and key insights you need to approach the certification exam with confidence. Access the latest schedule. 

 

Step 2- Get Specialized with the Associate Level Certifications

 If you already have the foundational knowledge in SAP BTP, you can delve into specialized certification tracks based on their career goals and interests. Professionals choose from distinct areas, including Application Development and Automation, Integration Database and Data Management, and AI Foundation. Each specialization offers focused certifications and provide the skills required to address specific business needs and technical challenges, equipping learners with the knowledge to advance their SAP careers.

For SAP Partners , you can join one of the Partner Get and Stay Certified Academies below that will help you with the certification exam. 

  • Partner Get Certified Academy for Security Administrator
  • Partner Get Certified Academy for Backend Developer – CAP
  • Partner Get Certified Academy for SAP Build – LCNC
  • Partner Get Certified Academy for Integration Developer
  • Partner Get Certified Academy for Backend Developer – ABAP Cloud

 

Step 3 - Become a SAP BTP Solution Architect

Experienced professionals can pursue the SAP BTP Solution Architect professional certification. From a career development perspective, this certification is marking the transition from a specialized skillset to a broader, strategic role. Solution architects are responsible for designing comprehensive SAP BTP implementations that align with business objectives and technical requirements.

  • For SAP Partners - Access Partner Get Certified Academy for SAP BTP Solution Architect

entry.title: Unlocking the Potential of SAP AI in Procurement
entry.content:
Hello, Martin Beganyi here again, Program Lead at Procurement Adoption Office.  

You may know me from my previous contributions as part of the Solution Value Advisory team for EMEA/MEE.

Recently, I have transitioned to the newly established Procurement Adoption Office, where I now lead two global adoption programs: one focused on driving the adoption of SAP Ariba’s Category Management solution, and the second dedicated to accelerating the uptake of AI-powered features across SAP Procurement solutions, specifically SAP Fieldglass and SAP Ariba - This blog is dedicated to the latter, the transformative role of SAP AI in Procurement. 

Through years, I’ve observed a consistent challenge: many organizations are unaware of the full suite of AI capabilities embedded in their SAP procurement solutions.  Despite the growing availability of these advanced features, adoption remain low or inconsistent, limiting the value customers can unlock. 

To address this, we have launched a global program to help customers to adopt AI features in core solutions for example, Strategic Sourcing, Fieldglass, and Buying. 

Introducing the AI Toolkit 

The cornerstone of our initiative is the AI Toolkit — a concise, easy-to-understand resource that compiles essential information about all available AI functionalities.  Designed for those new to AI, the toolkit cuts through the noise of overwhelming information, providing a clear starting point for customers and partners alike.  We encourage you to download, share, and leverage this toolkit within your teams:   

  • AI in Procurement Toolkit (Aug2025).pdf 

Should you prefer a solution-focused, high-level perspective, we are pleased to share our latest one-pagers:

  • SAP AI One Pager - Guided Buying
  • SAP AI One Pager - Guided Sourcing
  • SAP AI One Pager - SAP Ariba Category Management
  • SAP AI One Pager - SAP Fieldglass Contingent Workforce - Base AI

  • SAP AI One Pager - SAP Fieldglass Services Procurement - Premium AI
  • SAP AI One Pager - Joule in SAP Ariba Solutions
  • SAP AI One Pager - Joule in SAP Fieldglass Solutions

Engage with Our Interactive Learning Opportunities 

To further support adoption, we host a series of live webinars where we delve into the value of individual AI features, demonstrate activation steps, and showcase practical usage scenarios. Here are some of the upcoming sessions: 

  • Registration for On24 Sessions 

For our Preferred Success customers, we can offer a dedicated one-on-one expert led engagements, including hands-on activation of AI features aligned with your business needs. 

Join Our Open Office Hours 

Additionally, we run a recurring series of ‘Open’ hour to all SAP customers which offers a flexible way to ask questions, seek real-time answers, and gain clarity on AI capabilities. 

Upcoming ‘Open’ hours (EMEA/APAC - 10am CET):

  • Sept 23rd - Open Hour (EMEA/APAC)​ 
  • Oct 7th – Open Hour (EMEA/APAC)​

Next Steps 

We invite you to explore our AI Toolkit, participate in the webinars, or attend the SAP ‘Open’ hours.  To schedule a dedicated session tailored to your organization’s needs, please reach out to your Customer Success Manager who can support you.

entry.title: Evolving from Manual AI Deployment to Intelligent Operational Orchestration: A COO’s Viewpoint
entry.content:
Over the years, I have firsthand witnessed how organizations adopt new, advanced technologies. Some move forward with bold vision, while others take the next step cautiously, assessing the terrain with small, contained pilots. Artificial Intelligence is no exception. 

In the majority of boardrooms today, AI has undeniably become essential to business. Yet, it is often leveraged on a project-by-project basis – an analytics dashboard, a predictive model, or a chatbot for any other department. These projects are strategic foundations but usually fail to achieve holistic transformation. 

The concern isn’t the AI itself. It’s how enterprises deploy it – disconnected, incremental, and fragmented from an integrated business roadmap. The outcome? Teams functioning in isolation, information gets siloed, and tech leaders struggle to align AI investments towards tangible business results. 

This is why I believe we stand at an inflection point: the paradigm shifts from manual AI deployment to what I call intelligent operational orchestration. 

Beyond Disconnected Pilots 

Leveraging AI in an isolated fashion might lead to a false sense of advancement. A department might only see cost savings or efficiency gains, but the larger picture often remains the same. When insights fail to flow across different organizational departments, AI stays experimental rather than driving enterprise-wide transformation. 

To leap forward, organizations need to change their mindsets - AI is not a collection of standalone applications. It's the binding network of data with decisions, people with processes, linking strategy with execution, and modern operations. 

This highlights the path toward what I define as intelligent orchestration—a model where AI not only helps optimize tasks, but also orchestrates greater business outcomes. 

What Intelligent Operational Orchestration Actually Means 

At its heart, orchestration brings intelligence together across the enterprise. It advances beyond deploying more models or automation. Instead, it ensures that decision frameworks, processes, and data operate in unison. 

Think of this as migrating from a series of solo performances to a finely tuned symphony. The significant instruments - AI models, data pipelines, and automation workflows - are already present. Orchestration unites them, ensuring every component contributes efficiently at the right time to deliver exponential impact. 

In this context, orchestration helps enterprises to: 

  • Integrate intelligence into processes rather than considering it an extra. 
  • Allow cross-functional partnerships to break down silos where important information often stays confined. 
  • Align technology with strategy to ensure AI initiatives directly contribute to long-term goals. 

Orchestration: Significance and Relevance 

The timing could not have been more crucial. We live in a rapidly changing era, also defined by uncertainty like mounting competition, regulatory changes, shifting client behaviors, and supply chain disruptions. In such an ecosystem, organizations can’t rely on standalone improvements anymore; they require systemic agility. 

Intelligent operational orchestration helps with precisely the same. It delivers the most critical benefits enterprises should not overlook: 

  • Agility at Scale - Enterprises can respond rapidly to opportunities or disruptions because intelligence flows easily across functions and processes. 
  • Operational Efficiency - Orchestration helps eradicate duplicated efforts, redundant processes, and manual handoffs, which frees your employees to concentrate more on value-driven work. 
  • Future-Readiness - Because orchestration is flexible, organizations can upgrade their operating models without revamping from the start, every time the market changes. 

Data supports this! As per McKinsey’s research, organizations integrating AI across different workflows—not just in projects—illustrate 20–30% operational efficiency and solid market leverage. 

Lessons from the Field 

In my conversations with different global leaders, I’ve spotted a repeating trend - scale drives results. 

  • As per some reports by Deloitte, AI-driven financial automation can decrease closing time by up to 40% and enhance forecast accuracy by 20%.   
  • A global food and beverage manufacturer also leveraged ThroughPut’s AI platform, which recovered $0.5M in weekly productivity losses and increased output by 5% through reduced unplanned downtime and smarter machine utilization. 

These two stories highlight one crucial fact - AI serves as a revolutionary technology only when orchestrated, not when implemented in isolation. 

From The COO’s Desk: Guiding Leadership Amid Orchestration 

As a COO, I regard orchestration as not just be treated as a technical challenge but a core leadership responsibility. Success with AI goes beyond experimentation; it's more about integrating intelligence rooted at the core of the operating model. 

For leaders, this means: 

  • Adopting an Ecosystem Mindset 
    AI use cases should not only be restricted to departmental barriers. Leaders should foster collective intelligence, where every process benefits from the shared insights. 
  • Aligning AI with Strategic Results 
    Orchestration must deliver outcomes beyond efficiency. It should solidify resilience, improve client value, and unlock innovation. 
  • Scaling with Intention 
    Expanding orchestration abilities needs governance models and systems that scale with the business. Short-term pilots should grow into long-lasting capabilities. 
  • Encouraging Cultural Readiness 
    Most significantly, orchestration thrives on cultural alignment. Teams need to learn to trust AI-based information, emphasize enterprise-wide results, and collaborate across silos. 

Looking Ahead 

In my view, the next great stride for organizations is more than just scaling AI—it’s all about orchestrating it smartly. 

This transformation highlights the next phase of enterprise growth. What once started as an experimental project is now entering its prime with company-wide orchestration frameworks that help drive scalability and resilience. 

Successful enterprises treat AI adoption not as a forward-thinking experiment, but as a coordinator of operations—a key driver of adaptability, agility, and strategic resilience. 

From my perception, as a COO, the ultimate proof of success is not how widespread AI is being leveraged, but how smartly it is orchestrated.

entry.title: Understanding CNNs (Convolutional Neural Networks) in under 5 minutes
entry.content:
AI isn’t a dream of the future anymore; it’s all around us. With countless acronyms and concepts to grasp, one you can’t afford to ignore if you want to thrive at consulting is CNN, as it’s reshaping how companies operate and create value in digital economies. 

In this quick guide, we’ll break down what CNNs are, why they matter, and how you can start building the skills to bring this knowledge into your consulting career. 

👉Read through to the end for a resource that will help you take the first step in developing these skills. 

 
So, What is a CNN?  

A CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) is a type of deep brain network that takes hints from how we see. Inspired by the way human brains interpret visual signals, it spots lines, edges, shapes, and patterns. Unlike the “old brain” webs that "see" each bit alone, CNNs can keep track of where things are. This helps them deal with big sets of pics, clips, etc.  

Why Convolutional? Well, the CNNs maintain spatial relationships by using layers called “convolutions” Read more here 

How does a CNN run? (In 3 steps) 

  • The “Convolutional Layer” has three components: the input, which is an image, a kernel (also known as a filter) to detect features like lines, edges, or colors; and an output, which is a feature map summarizing the features found.   
  • The “Pooling Layer”: This layer simplifies the size of the feature map, keeping only the most important information.   
  • The “Fully Connected” Layer takes all that information and uses it to perform classification or regression tasks

What is the difference between CNN and DNN?  

  • A DNN, Deep Neural Network, is an “AI brain web” with lots of links. It sees facts piece by piece, making it good for tasks like seeing pics, hearing speech, & dealing with words.  
  • CNN is a kind of specialized DNN, well-suited for handling image data. The key difference is the ability to apply filters to the input image to extract key features. The information extracted through these layers is then passed to “fully connected layers,” which analyze the features and can generate predictions.   

 

 The big gap is what they do best: DNNs are all-around and work with many kinds of tasks. CNNs are top at jobs that need seeing & knowing visual facts.   

What are CNNs mainly used for

Tasks with Pics  

CNNs work well at sorting, classifying, and detecting objects in images. They have transformed how companies manage visual information: from predictive maintainance tasks in manufacturing to smart supply chain management.  

Dealing with Docs  

CNNs are widely used to automate the extraction of information from documents such as invoices, receipts, and contracts. Instead of relying on manual work or rigid rule-based systems, CNNs can identify and capture key data pointssuch as dates, monetary values, and vendor names with higher accuracy and speed. This also reduces human error, streamlines workflows, and ensures more reliable data for follow-up processes. 

Seeing Things Early  

As said, CNNs are great for looking at things. And they are the perfect ally in enterprise contexts to “see things early”. CNNs can help look at data coming from equipment and machinery, for instance, and detect patterns and anomalies that signal possible failures. This potentially cuts costs & keeps work smooth.  

CNNs in the SAP Ecosystem

The integration of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and other advanced AI technologies within SAP Business AI  is reshaping how businesses run and their competitiveness. 

This means clients will increasingly expect you to explain not only the technology, but also the business value it creates. By embedding artificial intelligence into foundational business systems, SAP enables enterprises to enhance operational efficiency, leverage data-driven insights, and drive sustained innovation. As the company continues to evolve its AI offerings, consultants who can connect these capabilities to business outcomes will be the ones helping organizations achieve long-term success in an increasingly competitive marketplace. 

👉If you want to kickstart your career in consulting, explore the SAP Young Professionals Program,  an initiative designed to upskill young talent in SAP’s latest solutions and prepare them as Associate Consultants, ready to deliver value across the SAP ecosystem.

entry.title: 🚀 SAP BTP Weekly: Practical AI, Enhanced Analytics, and a Vision for the Future
entry.content:
1. Joule Studio and No-Code AI Agents
Creating intelligent agents without coding is now possible in SAP Build. This opens the door for both business and IT teams to build copilots that answer questions and automate tasks quickly.

Beyond the no-code hype, the challenge is cultural: will users trust an internally developed agent? Imagine a procurement team building an agent to negotiate with suppliers—it speeds up the process, but what if the agent misinterprets company policies? Human oversight remains essential.

🔗 https://www.sap.com/spain/products/artificial-intelligence/joule-studio.html 

2. Joule for Consultants
A new program helps SAP consultants use Joule as a copilot during implementations. It includes guides, templates, and real-world use cases that can be applied directly to client projects.

The potential lies in reducing configuration time and accelerating deployments. But it also raises questions: to what extent will Joule replace manual tasks? For example, in a SuccessFactors project, it could generate initial configurations within minutes—though expert validation will always be required.

🔗 https://www.sap.com/spain/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant/sap-consulting-capability.html 

3. Integration with Event Mesh and Kafka
SAP Advanced Event Mesh now connects with Apache Kafka, enabling hybrid and decentralized architectures. This allows for more resilient micro-integrations compared to traditional point-to-point models.

The practical challenge lies in governance. A retail company might use it to synchronize inventories across multiple channels in seconds, but managing topics and ensuring traceability can become complex. SAP provides connectors, but the learning curve is real.

🔗 https://events.sap.com/eur-expertsession-aemkafka/en_us/home.html 

4. Real-World FinOps on BTP
Companies adopting FinOps on BTP are gaining visibility and achieving up to 20% reductions in cloud costs. Dashboards and alerts help CIOs and CFOs make faster decisions.

The challenge is organizational: finance and IT often “speak different languages.” Imagine a telco optimizing Integration Suite consumption—without internal agreements, discussions about who pays what can escalate. The technology is ready, governance isn’t always.

🔗 https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/enhanced-finops-capabilities-for-sap-btp/ba-p/14113797 

5. SAP Build Process Automation
New preconfigured processes allow automation of HR, compliance, and finance tasks in days. A “shortcut” for organizations seeking efficiency without large-scale projects.

The tricky part is resistance to change. An HR team may see value in automating vacation approvals, but users often fear losing control. SAP provides ready-to-use processes, but tailoring them to each organization still requires effort.

🔗 https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/public-site-for-sap-build-pre-built-content/ba-p/13562272 

6. BDC and Databricks: Next-Generation Analytics
The integration between SAP BTP Data & Analytics (BDC) and Databricks enables unification of SAP and non-SAP data in lakehouse environments for AI and advanced analytics.

Picture a mining company combining SAP financial data with IoT sensor data in Databricks: the predictive potential is enormous. The challenge lies in governance: without a clear model, “data democratization” can turn into chaos. SAP ensures traceability, but governance is each organization’s responsibility.

🔗 https://news.sap.com/2025/02/sap-databricks-open-bold-new-era-data-ai/ 

7. SAP Now Argentina – Business Highlights
The event showcased how local companies are applying SAP BTP and Joule to real business processes. Applied AI was the highlight, with use cases in retail, energy, and manufacturing.

Beyond the excitement, scalability remains a question. Can a successful pilot in one area be extended across the entire organization? Use cases inspire, but customers still need clarity on timelines and adoption costs.

🔗 https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/databricks.html 

8. SAP Customer Success Day – Our Experience
This week we had the privilege of meeting with over 20 customers in an exclusive workshop on enterprise integration, exploring the power of SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) and SAP Integration Suite.

Beyond the technology, what stood out was how different customers face similar challenges: shifting from point-to-point to event-driven models without losing control or simplicity. A bank raised the need to process thousands of transactions in real time; a retail company sought to orchestrate omnichannel inventory. Everyone agreed the key is not just the tool, but the ability to redesign processes.

🔗 https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7369726725749903369/ 

At the end of the day, BTP is experienced differently depending on the role: for a CIO it’s efficiency and control, for an architect it’s integration, for a Basis administrator it’s security, and for a consultant it’s delivery speed. Yet ultimately, we all face the same question: how do we create real business value from technology without getting lost in complexity?

entry.title: Joule Setup for SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
We're excited to announce that Joule, SAP’s AI-powered enterprise copilot, is officially integrated into SAP Digital Manufacturing. This marks the first-ever availability of Joule in the Digital Manufacturing domain, enabling manufacturers to tap into intelligent, conversational insights right within their production environments 

SAP Digital Manufacturing is a suite of cloud-based and on-premise solutions that enables manufacturers to digitize, monitor, control, and optimise their production operations in real time. It integrates manufacturing processes with enterprise business systems, bridging the gap between ERP (like SAP S/4HANA) and shop floor operations, supporting Industry 4.0 and smart factory initiatives. 

Core Capabilities Supported Scope 

  • Production Execution 
  • Enterprise and Shop Floor Integration 
  • Visual Work Instructions 
  • Quality Management 
  • Manufacturing Analytics & KPIs (via DMi) 
  • Production Orchestration & Monitoring 
  • Resource and Material Management 
  • Edge Integration / IoT Enablement 
  • Sustainability & Compliance 

 

Supported Languages:

This blog post is a series for Joule Activation: 

  • SAP Business AI – Overview for all !!! (Includes information on Joule Supported Data Centers, Different scenarios during Joule setup, etc..) 
  • Joule - Unified Setup: Bridging Simplicity and Performance (Demo Video to understand the Unified Setup, Joule basics & architecture, how to set up Joule, etc...)  
  • Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition - A Comprehensive Setup Guide 
  • Joule Setup – End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach 
  • Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide 
  • SAP Digital Supply Chain 
  • Joule for SAP Integrated Business Planning (SAP IBP) – Setup Guide 
  • Joule – Getting Started with Document Grounding - setup guide 
  • Activate Joule with SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start 
  • Analytics Insights in Joule – Setup Guide 
  • Joule in SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite – Setup Guide 
  • Joule Setup for SAP Integrated Product Development 

Joule for SAP Digital Manufacturing  (You are Here) 

Blogs - Work in Progress (WIP): 

  • SAP SuccessFactors Joule Activation (Refer to SAP Discovery Centre) 
  • SAP Digital Supply Chain (WIP) 
  • SAP Asset Performance Management 
  • SAP Product Lifecycle Management 
  • SAP Concur 
  • SAP Ariba 
  • and more to be added towards General Availability 

This blog will uncover the steps to activate Joule in two different ways: Section (1): create a Joule SAP Digital Manufacturing as a standalone product (Fresh activation), Section (2): Activating and adding Joule SAP Digital Manufacturing with an existing subaccount along with your other activated / current LoBs landscape  

**************************************************************************************************************************

Scenario 

You want to integrate the generative AI copilot Joule with your SAP Digital Manufacturing application and require information about what to consider when you want to use Joule. 

Use Cases 

The following feature is available for Joule in SAP Digital Manufacturing: 

Conversational search of application help: Ask Joule questions about the SAP Digital Manufacturing apps and processes, and Joule gives you an answer based on the SAP Digital Manufacturing documentation from the SAP Help Portal.  

Pre-requisites 

  • Ensure that you meet all requirements for Joule onboarding. For more information, refer to Prerequisites in the Joule Onboarding Guide. 
  • You have an entitlement for Joule in the same global account on SAP BTP as your entitlement for SAP Digital Manufacturing. 
  • You have subscribed to SAP Digital Manufacturing. 

 

Integration Process: 

If you are activating Joule for the very first time for your SAP Digital Manufacturing system, then we refer to it as a standalone/single setup, as mentioned in “Section 1”.   

In this standalone setup process, you may decide to use the same SAP BTP Subaccount to activate Joule, or you may plan to use a new subaccount or if you would like to add SAP Digital Manufacturing to an existing subaccount and activate Joule that can be used which is a unified setup as described below in “Section 2”. 

What does Unified Setup mean? 

The unified setup of Joule with multiple SAP products allows business users to ask any question irrespective of the Joule client they are in. This approach helps avoid toggling between multiple applications, improves user efficiency, and delivers a more consistent, connected experience across all LoBs. 

Check your setup plan: 

By now, we hope you've selected one of the setup plans. Before we begin activating Joule for SAP Digital Manufacturing, let’s take a moment to understand how Joule works. 

image below explains how Joule works with your landscape integration 

Note: In the current release of Joule for DM, we do not use the SAP Build Work Zone and Cloud Foundry services. This is planned for the next releases.    

Now, since you have a clear understanding about Digital Manufacturing and how Joule works now it is time for us to start the integration process:  

Let us have a look at the steps involved for the integration: 

**************************************************************************************************************************

Integrating Joule  

  • Step 1: Setup Plan:  
    • Section 1: New Digital Manufacturing setup with no prior Joule setup. 
    • Section 2: You have an existing Joule subaccount, and you want to enable Joule for Digital Manufacturing 

*************************************************************************************************************************

Step 1: Setup Plan 

Section 1: New Digital Manufacturing setup with no prior Joule setup. 

If you already have some experience with SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) we request you to follow the steps in this blog - Joule Setup – End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach. In this blog, please check Section 2 (Check your SAP BTP Account for Joule Entitlements. 

If this is your first time using the SAP DM (Digital Manufacturing) platform and you're unsure how to proceed with the activation, don’t worry - we’ve got you covered. Just follow the steps below to activate Joule for SAP DM easily.  

Fresh Digital Manufacturing setup – no existing Joule configuration 

  1. Create the Subaccount and choose the relevant Data Centre 
  2. Set up Trust Configuration with SAP Cloud Identity Service 
  3. Add Entitlements 
  4. Run the Booster and Integrations with the Product SAP Digital Manufacturing 
    • Note: Choose the SAP Digital Manufacturing Test as product to enable Joule in your SAP Digital Manufacturing quality tenant. 
  5. Add the role “Joule_User” from the dmc application to a role collection 
    • Note: Assign those business users to the role collection that needs to interact with Joule. 
  6. Configure trusted domains in identity authentication for the SAP Digital Manufacturing domain 
    • Note: For more information, refer to Configure Trust to the Identity Authentication Tenant. 
  7. Configure a trusted domain in SAP BTP Cockpit for the same SAP Digital Manufacturing system
    • Note: For more information, refer to Configure Trusted Domain in SAP BTP. 
  8. Add the DM_USER User Role Collection to Launch the Joule
  9. See Joule in Action 

Step (1): Create the Subaccount and choose the relevant Data Centre 

Check this blog and follow step No – 5 

Check this blog and follow step No – 4 

Step (2): Set up Trust Configuration with SAP Cloud Identity Service 

Check this blog and follow step No – 7 

 

 

 

Step (3): Add Entitlements 

Check this blog and follow step No – 8  

 

 

Step (4): Run the Booster and Integrations with the Product SAP Digital Manufacturing 

The complete setup process is documented in this blog. Step No. 10 explains the process. For simplification, we have the simplified steps and images below.  

  • Click on Global Account -> Select Booster -> Search for Joule -> Run the Booster  

 

The system will validate the entitlements required. Once it’s green, you can click on Next  

Select the SAP BTP Subaccount and click on Next  

Select Integrations, you will be able to see the options for SAP IPD, select it, and click on Next  

 

 

Once you select the DM System, you can click on Next, review the selections, and click on Finish. The booster will take 5-9 minutes to activate Joule and set up the integrations with your DM system.  

Joule will now return the success message after the integrations are completed. You can validate this setup by navigating to Systems and Formation, searching for the Joule formation that will be created for your setup, as shown below.   

Step (5): Add the role “Joule_User” from the dmc application to a role collection 

  • After the booster run has completed and formation checks, add the role “Joule_User” from the dmc application to a role collection.  
  • Assign those business users to the role collection that needs to interact with Joule. 

Click on Subaccount -> Role Collections -> Create -> Joule_User -> Edit -> Role Name 

 

Step (6): Configure trusted domains in identity authentication for the SAP Digital Manufacturing domain 

  • For more information, refer to Configure Trust to the Identity Authentication Tenant. 

Open Cloud Identity Services -> click on Applications & Resources -> External Services -> Trusted Domains -> Add 

 

Step (7): Configure a trusted domain in SAP BTP Cockpit for the same SAP Digital Manufacturing system 

  • For more information, refer to Configure Trusted Domain in SAP BTP. 

Open Sub Account -> Security -> Settings -> Trusted Domains -> Add  

Step (8): Assign the role in Subaccount to launch the Joule 

Open Sub Account -> Security -> Role Collection > Create -> Add (DM_ROLE) 

 

 Step (9)  See Joule in Action

Congratulations on successfully setting up the SAP DM Standalone system!  

  
Now, let’s walk through how to add SAP DM to your existing subaccount alongside your other active Lines of Business (LoBs).  

Step 1: Setup Plan 

Section 2: You have an existing Joule subaccount, and you want to enable Joule for DM. In this option, we will show you how to activate DM in the context of an existing Joule formation. Within your SAP BTP Global Account, navigate to System Landscapes, click on Formations  

Search for the Joule formation you have already set up. In my case, “I am using one of the existing formations, which has multiple SAP products connected to one Joule instance, as shown below”. You can click on Include Systems.   

 

In the new window, filter for SAP Digital Manufacturing and click on Next step.   

 

Select the option “Enable Capability Deployment” and “Enable the Joule Icon in Integrated System” and click on Review 

 

Validate the selections and click on Include.   

The process may take 5 to 8 minutes to complete, and you should be able to see the synchronizing option, as shown image below. 

 

Once the status turns green and Ready, we are good to use Joule with Digital Manufacturing capabilities.  

Congratulations on successfully setting up SAP Digital Manufacturing with the Unified Approach! 

In a similar approach, you may use Joule with a unified experience in other SAP products that you have integrated in the same subaccount. 

If you have any questions about the setup, you can reach us at SAP_AI_RIG@sap.com  

Thank you for staying connected with our blog and successfully activating Joule for SAP Digital Manufacturing ! 

 
We hope you’ve had an exciting experience exploring the power of Joule, your intelligent business companion. From insightful decisions to streamlined processes, we trust you’re already seeing the incredible value Joule brings to your day-to-day work. 

Here’s smarter, faster, and more impactful outcomes powered by Joule! 🚀

entry.title: Unlock the Future of Your Organization with Our New SAP Business AI Onboarding Resource Center!
entry.content:
Greetings, AI Enthusiasts!

Introducing our ORC page: your gateway to lay the foundation for success with SAP Business AI!

Ready to unleash the potential of SAP Business AI and bring intelligent automation, innovation, and efficiency into your organization? A strong start is crucial for successful adoption. Our Onboarding Resource Center for Business AI is crafted to guide you through each step of effective SAP Business AI implementation.

What Awaits You?

  • Detailed overviews of Joule, Embedded AI, and AI Foundation on SAP BTP.
  • Enlightening insights into responsible AI principles and secure implementation practices.

  • Essential guides for access and security setup using Cloud Identity Services.

Your Onboarding Journey: Three Core Phases to Success

The SAP Business AI Onboarding Resource Center content is strategically structured to accompany you from understanding to effective implementation within your business processes.

Phase 1: Get Started with SAP

Objective: Establish a strong foundation by comprehending SAP’s AI portfolio and the tools available to you.


Key Highlights:

  • Learn how to configure secure access with Cloud Identity Services for AI implementation.

Phase 2: Plan Your Implementation

Objective: Align AI adoption with your business strategy and empower your organization for success.

Key Highlights:

  • Define clear, business-aligned AI objectives that accentuate your strategic priorities.
  • Employ structured project execution utilizing the SAP BTP AI Best Practices Guide.
  • Examine over 200 real-world AI use cases to identify and validate pilot opportunities.
  • Review proven solution architectures in the AI Architecture Center and explore the AI Catalog in SAP Discovery Center.
  • Access On-demand SAP Business AI Onboarding Webcasts to educate yourself at your own pace, covering foundational concepts and practical implementation insights.
  • Integrate governance, security, and change management best practices for enduring success.

Phase 3: Get Enabled

Objective: Equip your team with the skills and resources needed to implement and scale transformative AI solutions.

Key Highlights:

  • Engage with free learning resources and role-specific enablement content.
  • Follow AI guides tailored to solution areas such as BTP, ERP, CX, Supply Chain, and HR.
  • Connect with experts and peers through the SAP Community.
  • Seize the opportunity for hands-on learning through SAP Learning.

In Conclusion:

The SAP Business AI Onboarding Resource Center is purpose-built to help you move from initial understanding to impactful business outcomes. By combining strategic planning, secure and responsible implementation, and targeted enablement, you’ll be ready to deliver real value from AI across your organization.

Your journey to SAP Business AI success begins now—let’s make it happen!

3. AI in Integration Suite

Best Regards,

Medha Patki | SAP BTP Onboarding Advisor

Customer Onboarding Center

entry.title: Keeping the human in human resources: The future of HR in the age of AI
entry.content:
As artificial intelligence moves beyond automating admin tasks and begins shaping decisions, culture, and careers, HR leaders are asking: 

👉 What does it mean to keep the “human” in human resources? 

Katherine Gibbard, PhD and Autumn D. Krauss, Ph.D. from the Future of Work Research Lab at SAP SuccessFactors partnered with Aadesh Goyal (formerly Tata Communications), Herman Rolfers (The HEINEKEN Company), Rajamma Krishnamurthy (Microsoft), Marquam Piros (Seagate Technology), Mark Sankarsingh (PepsiCo), Dante Palazzo (Grupo Nós), and 8 other global HR executives explore the future of HR in the age of AI. 

The result? A bold, actionable vision for what’s next. 

📌 In our new research report, Keeping the Human in Human Resources: The Future of HR in the Age of AI, you’ll discover: 

🔹 Which human capabilities will become essential (and why empathy, ethics, and leadership matter more than ever) 
🔹 Where HR needs to upskill now to stay relevant and strategic 
🔹 The six emerging archetypes of future-ready HR professionals 
🔹 How AI can actually make HR more human 

This isn’t a story about humans versus artificial intelligence. It’s about how we design a future where humans and AI work together to elevate the employee experience, strengthen culture, and lead with conscience. 

📖 Dive into the full research report.

Let’s not just keep up with change — let’s lead it. #FutureOfWork #HRLeadership #AI #HRStrategy #HumanResources #HRTransformation

entry.title: AI-driven, Joule-enabled Warehouse Resource & Operations Management for SAP EWM on S/4 HANA 2023
entry.content:
It is a topic in every warehouse: Supervisors and Warehouse Operations Managers would like to see their planned workload for the day and see in real-time whether shipping times will be met. If shipping times are in jeopardy, the warehouse system is then expected to evaluate if an optimized resource allocation could pro-actively solve any potential delays. When a more optimal usage of the available resources is found, resources should automatically be directed to the critical areas. Being able to take action proactively is of the essence, because we do not want to only take action when we are already in delay.

The following is an example of an AI-driven, Joule enabled Application that can accomplish the above outlined requirements and activities supported by AI. The Application leverages the embedded AI in the EWM Private Cloud Edition S/4 HANA 2023 FPS03 release and the Joule Studio available in SAP Build.

 

 

The Architecture of the Application looks as follows:

 

AI-based Warehouse Workload Visibility

In the current version of the Application, the expected workloads of picking and packing operations are calculated leveraging the embedded AI capabilities in SAP EWM, which are then displayed in the UI5 Application (see in the example below):

It is also clearly visible in which Activity Area the workload is currently exceeding the planned Resource capacity.

The Application then further allows a manual simulation of adding or removing Resources to evaluate the impact in a given activity area. 

The fully "automatic rebalancing" function evaluates whether it is possible to optimize the resource allocation to the different areas, considering the allowed resource types in an Activity Area.

If an optimized resource allocation is possible, the warehouse operations manager, can accept these changes and the resources will be reassigned in the EWM system so that they will receive workload to execute from the new area.

Joule-enabled with custom EWM Joule Skills

Further more the current version of the Application provides Joule support for Warehouse Operations Management with the following Joule Skills:

- Joule Skill 1: Current Workload Analysis: Provide a comprehensive analysis of the current workload associated with picking and packing operations, considering the current resource allocation across different warehouse areas, as well as dependent scheduling of packing activities.
- Joule Skill 2: Provide Optimized Resource Allocation: Simulate an optimal workforce allocation strategy to mitigate bottlenecks and criticalities within the warehouse operations, to avoid shipping delays.
- Joule Skill 3: Accept Optimized Resource Allocation: Accept the optimization results and reassign the resources in EWM to the new areas.   

Coming soon an AI Agent will be introduce that autonomously orchestrates workforce allocation (monitored by the supervisor).

For more Information on this Application & AI functionality please contact SAP Services (EWMServices@sap.com).

entry.title: Agentic AI – AI which finally makes sense?
entry.content:
“A computer can never be held accountable, therefore a computer must never make a management decision.” – IBM Training Manual, 1979[1][2]

So, where are we with AI now? Isn’t Agentic AI doing exactly what it isn’t supposed to do?

AI or ML or?

We are bombed with terms – small break! Let’s digest this grocery of terms…

  • Data Science[3] is a broad interdisciplinary scientific field using scientific methods to extract knowledge and insights from the massive data sets. It uses both; traditional data mining, data analysis and statistical methods; as well as ML techniques, to accomplish the given tasks.
  • AI (Artificial Intelligence) is the broadest concept, aiming to create machines that can "think" and perform human-like tasks.
  • ML (Machine Learning)[3] is a subset of AI where algorithms learn from data without explicit programming, enabling predictions and pattern recognition. It does need Data Science to be employed first to clean, prepare and analyze unstructured big data
  • Deep Learning[4] is a type of ML based on artificial neural networks impersonating human “thinking”.

Neither ML nor AI are something brand new. It is considered that earliest ML “program” was introduced in the early 1950s (by Arthur Samuel). Mid 1950s was the time when AI somehow emerged as well. However, only in 2000s ML/AI started being more popular – simply because machines could not cope with the complex ML/AI processing, before that time. The real break-through (sort-of) came only in 2012 with Deep-Learning. Everything else is now a “legend”…

Figure 1. Data Science as a discipline

Is this the correct relationship between ML and AI?

There are somewhat different views, but let’s stick with the one which is the most common; Deep Learning is a subset of ML, ML is subset of AI, and Data Science is here to “help” them all. Still let me just mention – some other interpretation would put “all” under umbrella of Dats Science, while some views say that AI is only “partially overlapping” with ML and Deep Learning. However, we will (at least in this article) stay with the relationships as presented in this diagram.

Generative AI

AI is great, but next big evolution happened with Generative AI (or GenAI)[5].

So, what is Generative AI? While AI is very broad field of computer science focused on enabling machines to perform human-like tasks, Generative AI is a specialized subset of AI (or Traditional AI, as often referred) that creates new, original content such as text, images, or music – impersonating human-like creativity.

When we talk about GenAI, sometimes we mixed it with LLM (Large Language Model) – but this is, of course, not correct. GenAI encompasses various forms of content generation, while LLM is a foundation model for NLP (Natural Language Processing) tasks – oriented to text understanding and generation only.

Both GenAI, in general, and LLM are in the essence based on Deep Learning models.

Figure 2. Generative AI

Whether we talk about text, or image or music creation, the flow is basically the same; there is a prompt (usually created by the user), invoking GenAI processing of the request to understand and generate appropriate content (i.e. text or answer on the specific inquiry), and finally there is a GenAI generated response returned to the requestor.

Agentic AI

And here we come to Agentic AI, next big hype – AI which makes sense? AI which can make actual decisions!

In general, it is scary – I admit. But at least, now we have a concept which can really, really be useful in the daily work. Do not take me wrong GenAI is also useful for quite a few things, but it was mostly limited to do some recommendations, suggestions etc.– it was more as an assistant helping us do the work, but we still had to make decisions and do the work by ourselves. But now with Agentic AI we actually have a tool which can make the decision and do the actual work. Yes, it is scary really – but it is a reality, as well…

Agentic AI[6][7] is an AI system, with enhanced autonomy, enabling it to independently set goals, make decision on it, plan actions accordingly, and finally execute necessary tasks, without human intervention. Unlike Traditional AI, or “only” Generative AI, Agentic AI Systems are capable to understand complex context, learn from the interactions, and adapt to changing conditions. Within its “core”, Agentic AI Systems integrate LLMs – to work together with other agents. Agents can be other ML models, but those could be also calls to external tools (i.e. like API calls, DB actions etc.). In the system, through AI Orchestration each agent is performing specific subset of tasks required to reach the overall goal.

Figure 3. Agentic AI System has “brain”, “memory” and “tools”

It is exactly because of “agents” working with LLM “brain”, this approach is demonstrating high autonomy in solving problems; from understanding the context, invoking the right agents to perform “micro” tasks; aggregating all results, measure the success rate in meeting the goal, make the decision and execute the actions.

Agentic AI is focused on decisions as opposed to creating the content, like GenAI. Agentic AI does not rely on human prompts and does not require human supervision. But Agentic AI and GenAI tools work together, each of them takes their own role. In fact, Agentic AI could not do what it does, if there are no GenAI capabilities – core of the Agentic AI System relies on GenAI to make actions on the initial prompts (or inputs invoking specific agents via AI Orchestration), evaluating responses received form the agents, and generating final human-like responses on the prompts (if such actions is needed).

Figure 4. An example of steps within Agentic AI System

In real terms, the process could look like this:

  1. Agentic AI System uses its brain (i.e. LLMs) to understand the context (i.e. understand that prompt is asking for the specific Sales Order status) and generate the content for the external tool agents (i.e. API call to the ERP system).
  2. Usually, Agentic AI System will also have memory to store past context – to be smarter with similar prompts in future.
  3. AI Orchestration will invoke tools which will perform specific tasks (i.e. read the Sales Order detail from the ERP system, read LMD delivery status, retrieve knowledge from RAG or simply engage other agent) and return the results to the brain.
  4. All responses will be aggregated (i.e. if we are invoking several tools).
  5. Agentic AI brain may evaluate the conditions (if met) or it may measure success rate toward set goals (if satisfaction level reached).
  6. At the end, Agentic AI brain may trigger some actions, including providing response to the requester –this time it will create the content (i.e. human-like response with the Sales Order status).

Another typical example would be autonomous vehicles (or self-driving cars), where car AI must understand the complex context of the surrounding driving conditions, take the necessary inputs, and act toward reaching the goal. In this process car AI will make autonomous driving decisions and steer the vehicle accordingly.

This is why Agentic AI is Ai which actual does make sense – as it actually can work for us… Of course, will it (eventually) work only for us – this is completely different topic – which I will try to address in the separate article.

Some more practical examples, addressing some additional topics about A2A, MCP including some SAP specific topics like Content Based Agents vs. Code Based Agents – I will also try to cover in the separate article.

And don’t worry. Agentic AI is current hype – but AI is evolving, there will more and more “hypes” in the future, I am quite certain…

Final Thoughts

So, Agentic AI makes decisions – and not only that, but they also execute actions! Let’s think about future and “real” self-driving cars!

Then, are we actually violating the principles set by IBM in 1979? I am not going to answer this question, but answer seems to be quite straight-forward, right?

Welcome to the future…

Acknowledgment

*) Intro photo by Nahrizul Kadri on Unsplash

**) This article uses SAP Business Technology Platform Solution Diagrams & Icons as per SAP Terms of Use  governing the use of these SAP Materials (please note, newer version of the Solution Diagrams & Icons, as well as Terms of Use, might be in place after the publication of this article).

More guidelines on Solution Diagrams & Icons can be found in this article by Bertram Ganz.

References

[1] IBM: AI decision-making: Where do businesses draw the line? | IBM

[2] LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7271085510142439426/

[3] IBM: Data science vs. machine learning: What's the Difference? | IBM

[4] Wikipedia: Deep learning - Wikipedia

[5] Forbes: The Difference Between Generative AI And Traditional AI: An Easy Explanation For Anyone

[6] IBM: What Is Agentic AI? | IBM

[7] IBM: Agentic AI vs. Generative AI | IBM

entry.title: Unlocking the Potential of Artificial Intelligence in Enhancing User Experience in SAP Guided Buying
entry.content:
Hi there and welcome to my latest blog. 

My name is Angeline Gregory, I am one of the Solution Value Advisors based in the UK.  The world of procurement is continuously evolving, and with it are the tools and technologies aimed at optimizing organizational spend.  Here, I am excited to present my blog on how artificial intelligence can elevate the user experience in SAP Guided Buying.

SAP Guided Buying can steer users towards more efficient and compliant buying processes.  It is crucial to integrate advanced technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) into your buying processes to enrich the experience.

The below features in SAP Guided Buying make purchasing decisions smoother and smarter and hence improve cost effectiveness and increases compliance.

Catalog Item Recommendation

The item recommendation feature suggests products and services based on users' past purchases.  It collects purchasing history from your organization and uses artificial intelligence to recommend catalog items that might be of interest based on the individual user. Item recommendations display in a carousel at the top of the home page, in the item details page or as alternatives to non-catalog item.

This feature improves productivity by:

  • Encouraging usage of catalog item when creating a non-catalog request​
  • Reducing effort when searching for items​
  • Reducing distractions when browsing
  • Improving user experience ​

Enable this feature by turning on the below parameters in SAP Guided Buying:

  • PARAM_ENABLE_ITEM_RECOMMENDATIONS
  • PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH

Note:

  • This feature is embedded AI-Feature included in your Guided Buying subscription 
  • At first SAP Guided Buying will show “Popular Items” based on organization’s most frequent purchases.  AI will learn and start showing “Recommended for you” items / services based on users clicks​.

Guided Buying Usage Report

The usage report in Guided Buying gives administrators insight into user searches, purchases, and overall interaction with SAP Guided Buying. SAP Guided Buying generates this report monthly to provides usage details, such as the number of users who signed in, number of users who added items to their cart, total number of items added to carts, and searches that returned no results.  This report helps answer business questions like which catalog areas to expand and the most popular search items.  By leveraging the insights from the Usage Report, organizations can continuously improve user experience based on data.

This feature improves efficiency by:

  • Highlighting opportunities based on user behavior, search patterns​ and search effectiveness analysis​
  • Aids making catalog improvements and helps bring spend under management​
  • Providing evidence- to make quicker design decisions

Enable this feature by turning on the below parameters in SAP Guided Buying:

  • PARAM_ENABLE_USAGE_REPORTS
  • PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH

Note:

  • ​This feature is embedded AI-Feature included in your Guided Buying subscription
  • SAP Guided Buying generates reports only after at least 100 unique users have cumulatively clicked “Add to cart” more than 1,000 times.  It must first collect and analyze a significant number of searching and purchasing actions 

​By using these features in guided buying systems, organizations can significantly help shape the way users buy goods or services.

Integrating AI and ML into guided buying isn't just about improving technology; it's about strategically enhancing the procurement process better suited to users' needs, while staying compliant and cost effective.

So, whether you are just starting out or looking to refine your procurement processes, consider how AI and ML can make a significant impact on your organization's guided buying system and watch as your bottom line and operational efficiencies improve.

Take the next steps by having a look at our comprehensive one-pager on AI and ML in SAP Guided Buying.

Thank you for reading my blog!!
